citations.narrative:
The licensee stated that the rabbits' food receptacles are being cleaned weekly with water, soap, and a sponge only,
without any sanitization. Unsanitary food receptacles can cause illness and disease in the rabbits. All food receptacles
shall be kept clean and sanitized at least once every 2 weeks.
Corrected at time of inspection.

The licensee stated the rabbits' water bowl is being cleaned weekly with water, soap, and a sponge only, without any
sanitization. Unclean and/or unsanitary water receptacles can cause illness and disease in the rabbits. All watering
receptacles shall be sanitized when dirty and at least once every 2 weeks.
Corrected at time of inspection.

The food receptacles for the lemurs are hand washed with soap, water, and a sponge weekly without any sanitization
product used, per the licensee. Therefore, the food receptacles are not being properly sanitized. Not sanitizing the food
receptacles appropriately creates risk for contamination by excreta, pests and/or disease. Food receptacles must be kept
clean and must be sanitized at least once every 2 weeks using one of the following methods: 1) live steam under
pressure, or 2) washing with hot water (at least 180 degrees Fahrenheit) and soap or detergent, or 3) washing all soiled
surfaces with appropriate detergent/disinfectant product that accomplishes the same purpose, with a thorough cleaning of
the surfaces to remove organic material first, and then to provide sanitization followed by a clean water rinse, or as often
as necessary to provide for the health and well-being of the animals.
Corrected at time of inspection.

The water receptacles for the lemurs are hand washed with soap, water, and a sponge weekly without any sanitization
product used, per the licensee, Therefore, the water receptacles are not being properly sanitized. Not sanitizing the water
receptacles appropriately creates risk for contamination by excreta, pests and/or disease. Water receptacles must be kept
clean and must be sanitized at least once every 2 weeks using one of the following methods: 1) live steam under
pressure, or 2) washing with hot water (at least 180 degrees Fahrenheit) and soap or detergent, or 3) washing all soiled
surfaces with appropriate detergent/disinfectant product that accomplishes the same purpose, with a thorough cleaning of
the surfaces to remove organic material first, and then to provide sanitization followed by a clean water rinse, or as often
as necessary to provide for the health and well-being of the animals.
Corrected at time of inspection.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by AUGUST 19, 2024, or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Since your existing USDA license has expired as of June 21, 2024, you cannot conduct any regulated activity until a
relicensing inspection accompanied by an inspection report with no non-compliances is received, and your license is
active again.
n

narrative:
3.54(b) 
   
Feeding. 
The licensee stated that the rabbits' food receptacles are being cleaned weekly with water, soap, and a sponge only, 
without any sanitization. Unsanitary food receptacles can cause illness and disease in the rabbits. All food receptacles 
shall be kept clean and sanitized at least once every 2 weeks. 
Corrected at time of inspection. 
3.55  Repeat
   
Watering. 
The licensee stated the rabbits' water bowl is being cleaned weekly with water, soap, and a sponge only, without any 
sanitization. Unclean and/or unsanitary water receptacles can cause illness and disease in the rabbits. All watering 
receptacles shall be sanitized when dirty and at least once every 2 weeks. 
Corrected at time of inspection. 
3.82(d)  Repeat
   
Feeding. 
The food receptacles for the lemurs are hand washed with soap, water, and a sponge weekly without any sanitization 
product used, per the licensee. Therefore, the food receptacles are not being properly sanitized. Not sanitizing the food 
receptacles appropriately creates risk for contamination by excreta, pests and/or disease. Food receptacles must be kept 
clean and must be sanitized at least once every 2 weeks using one of the following methods: 1) live steam under 
pressure, or 2) washing with hot water (at least 180 degrees Fahrenheit) and soap or detergent, or 3) washing all soiled 
surfaces with appropriate detergent/disinfectant product that accomplishes the same purpose, with a thorough cleaning of 
the surfaces to remove organic material first, and then to provide sanitization followed by a clean water rinse, or as often 
as necessary to provide for the health and well-being of the animals. 
Corrected at time of inspection. 
3.83  Repeat
   
Watering.

The water receptacles for the lemurs are hand washed with soap, water, and a sponge weekly without any sanitization 
product used, per the licensee, Therefore, the water receptacles are not being properly sanitized. Not sanitizing the water 
receptacles appropriately creates risk for contamination by excreta, pests and/or disease. Water receptacles must be kept 
clean and must be sanitized at least once every 2 weeks using one of the following methods: 1) live steam under 
pressure, or 2) washing with hot water (at least 180 degrees Fahrenheit) and soap or detergent, or 3) washing all soiled 
surfaces with appropriate detergent/disinfectant product that accomplishes the same purpose, with a thorough cleaning of 
the surfaces to remove organic material first, and then to provide sanitization followed by a clean water rinse, or as often 
as necessary to provide for the health and well-being of the animals. 
Corrected at time of inspection. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by AUGUST 19, 2024, or the applicant will forfeit the license 
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Since your existing USDA license has expired as of June 21, 2024, you cannot conduct any regulated activity until a 
relicensing inspection accompanied by an inspection report with no non-compliances is received, and your license is 
active again.
